p.content: Nouns are the words which principally describe persons, animals, places or things. They can also be used to express ideas, thoughts or emotions.
The following sections cover noun agreement, case and possession in
. The types of noun compounds allowed in
are given in section
. All of the elements than can modify nouns in full nominal phrases are covered in section
Agreement between at least some of the modifiers and the head noun may be requiured in number, animacy, gender, class or other features.

Many languages require agreement between at least some of the modifiers and the head noun. While English only has number agreement, in other languages this agreement may also include animacy, gender, class or other features.
In

case.caseText: there is no number agreement. Instead, number marking comes from the number or quantifier.
the various nominal modifiers agree in number with the head noun.

p.content: Examples showing number agreement in
nominal phrases include:
There is no agreement in animacy, gender, class or other features between the modifiers and the head noun.
The modifiers and the head noun agree in class. Examples showing class agreement in
nominal phrases include:
A classifier which agrees with the class or type of the noun is present with nouns that are counted or specified, but other modifiers are not marked for class, as shown in the following examples:
Examples showing animacy agreement between the head noun and its modifiers in
nominal phrases include:
The noun and its modifiers agree in gender in
, as shown in the followng examples:
Nominal phrases in
show agreement in ___
. Examples of this type of agreement include:
Nouns and their modifiers may also be marked for case. Case systems help distinguish the role of a noun or pronoun with respect to the verb.

Nouns and their modifiers may be marked for case. The most common case system is nominative-accusative. This is the system English has, though only pronouns are marked for case in English. In a nominative-accusative system, subjects of both transitive and intransitive verbs are in nominative case, while direct objects are accusative case. Possessors are genitive case. The nominative pronouns in English are:
p.langData: I, we, you, he, she, they
p.content: . The accusative pronouns are:
p.langData: me, us, you, him, her, them
p.content: . The genitive pronouns include:
p.langData: my, our, your, his, her, their
p.content: . Therefore, we say
and not
A language with a basic nominative-accusative case system may have different case marking for Experiencer subjects than for Agent subjects. Some verbs with Experiencer subjects are
p.langData: appear, see, fear, be found, want, like
p.content: and

In an ergative-absolutive case system, subjects of transitive verbs are marked with the ergative case, while objects of transitive verbs and subjects of intransitive verbs are marked with the absolutive case. The case of possessors is not set cross-linguistically. Some languages with an ergative-absolutive system simply have different sets of verbal agreement markers, but no marking on nouns. This type of agreement marking will be handled in section

Some languages are even more complex in that they normally have a nominative-accusative case system but under some grammatical conditions, such as a particular tense or aspect or a particular person agreement feature, the case system switches to ergative-absolutive. This is called “split ergativity”.

case.caseText: does not have any case system. The exact same set of pronouns may be used in any position in the sentence and there is no marking on nouns or on any noun modifiers based on their position in the sentence.

has a nominative-accusative case system. Subjects of both transitive and intransitive verbs are marked in the same way and use the same set of pronouns, but objects of transitive verbs are marked differently.

has an ergative-absolutive case system. Subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs are marked in the same way and use the same set of pronouns, but subjects of transitive verbs are marked differently.
has a split case system. The language normally follows the nominative-accusative case system, but the ergative-absolutive system is used under certain grammatical conditions.

text.content: The conditions where the ergative-absolutive case system is used are ___

p.content: This is shown in the following examples of transitive sentences with Agent subjects where the subject and object are nominal phrases:
Note the forms of the pronouns used for the Agent subject and object in these transitive sentences:
In the intransitive examples with nominal phrases as the subjects,

case.caseText: the case marking matches that of the subejcts in the transitive sentences above.
the case marking matches that of the objects in the transitive sentences above.
the case marking on most of the subjects matches that of the subjects in the transitive sentences above, but in certain situations, it matches that of the objects in trantitive sentences.

p.content: The examples of intransitive sentences with independent pronouns as subjects verify that

case.caseText: there is no case distinction, as the same pronouns can appear as subjects of both transitive and intransitive verbs and as objects of transitive verbs.
the same set of pronouns can appear as subjects of both transitive and intransitive verbs, while different pronouns are used as objects of transitive verbs.
the same set of pronouns can appear as subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs, while different pronouns are used as subjects of transitive verbs.

the same set of pronouns can normally appear as subjects of both transitive and intransitive verbs, while different pronouns are used as objects of transitive verbs. However, in certain cases, the same set of pronouns can appear as subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs, while different pronouns are used as subjects of transitive verbs.

p.content: In

case.caseText: the same case marking and pronoun set is used for both Agent and Experiencer subjects.

Experiencer subjects use the same case marking and pronoun set as objects of transitive verbs with an Agent subject do. We assume that Experiencer subjects have dative case, like indirect objects, so accusative case and dative case are marked the same in this language.
Experiencer subjects use a case marking and pronoun set which is distinct from both the subject and object of verbs with an Agent subject. This is the dative case, also used for indirect objects.

p.content: In

case.caseText: the same pronoun set is used for both Agent and Experiencer subjects.

Experiencer subjects use the same pronoun set as objects of transitive verbs with an Agent subject do. We assume that Experiencer subjects have dative case, like indirect objects, so the accusative and dative pronouns are the same in this language.
Experiencer subjects use a pronoun set which is distinct from both the subject and object of verbs with an Agent subject. These are the dative pronouns, also used for indirect objects.

p.content: In

case.caseText: the same case marking and pronoun set is used for both Agent and Experiencer subjects.

Experiencer subjects use the same case marking and pronoun set as objects of transitive verbs with an Agent subject do. We assume that Experiencer subjects have dative case, like indirect objects, so absolutive case and dative case are marked the same in this language.
Experiencer subjects use a case marking and pronoun set which is distinct from both the subject and object of verbs with an Agent subject. This is the dative case, also used for indirect objects.

p.content: In

case.caseText: the same pronoun set is used for both Agent and Experiencer subjects.

Experiencer subjects use the same pronoun set as objects of transitive verbs with an Agent subject do. We assume that Experiencer subjects have dative case, like indirect objects, so the absolutive and dative pronouns are the same in this language.
Experiencer subjects use a pronoun set which is distinct from both the subject and object of verbs with an Agent subject. These are the dative pronouns, also used for indirect objects.

p.content: In
, the same pronoun set is used for both Agent and Experiencer subjects.
In
, at least some of the pronouns used for Experiencer subjects are distinct from those used for Agent subjects.
This is shown in the following examples of transitive sentences with verbs which have Experiencer subjects, where the subject and object are nominal phrases:
Note the forms of the pronouns used for the Experiencer subjects and the objects in these transitive sentences:

There are additional cases for the minor grammatical relations which may be marked on the nominal phrases in languages which mark case on nouns. Languages without any case marking and those which only show case in the pronouns normally express these additional grammatical relations via adpositional phrases.

There are more cases to consider beyond that of the subject and object, also. These may include ablative case for a source or origin, genitive case for kinds or possessors, dative case for indirect objects, instrumental case for means or instruments, locative case for locations, vocative case for direct address, and oblique case is sometimes used for the minor grammatical relations. These additional cases are usually marked via case markers on the nominal phrases themselves in languages which normally mark case on nouns or nominal phrases as well as pronouns. For languages without any case marking and those which only show case in the pronouns, these additional grammatical relations are normally expressed via adpositional phrases.
In
, there are not any kind of case distinctions. Therefore, the minor grammatical relations are expressed by

case.caseText: prepositional
postpositional
prepositional or postpositional
adpositional

p.content: phrases, rather than by nominal phrases (see section
In
, case distinctions are not marked on nouns or nominal phrases; only the pronoun sets distinguish case. Therefore, the minor grammatical relations are expressed by

case.caseText: prepositional
postpositional
prepositional or postpositional
adpositional

p.content: phrases, rather than by nominal phrases (see section
). The case distinctions in the pronouns will be delineated in section
In
, case is marked on both pronouns and nouns or nominal phrases.

text.content: Nominative case is the default (unmarked) case.

Other
case markers attach to the beginning of the initial word in the nominal phrase.
case markers attach to the end of the final word in the nominal phrase.
case markers attach to the beginning of the initial word and some attach to the end of the final word in the nominal phrase.
case markers are prefixes which attach to the head noun.
case markers are suffixes which attach to the head noun.
case markers are prefixes and some are suffixes which attach to the head noun.
case markers are clitics which attach to either the beginning of the initial word or the end of the final word in the nominal phrase and some are affixes which attach to the head noun.
Some may also attach ___
Some of the case markers attach ___
The case markers attach to the beginning of the initial word in the nominal phrase.
The case markers attach to the end of the final word in the nominal phrase.
Some of the case markers attach to the beginning of the initial word and some attach to the end of the final word in the nominal phrase.
The case markers are prefixes which attach to the head noun.
The case markers are suffixes which attach to the head noun.
Some of the case markers are prefixes and some are suffixes which attach to the head noun.
Some of the case markers are clitics which attach to either the beginning of the initial word or the end of the final word in the nominal phrase and some are affixes which attach to the head noun.
Some may also attach ___
The case markers attach ___

p.content: The case markers used on nouns or nominal phrases in
are shown in the following table.

col.content: subjects of transitive verbs and possessors
subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs
subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs and possessors

p.content: Possession can normally be expressed by a pronoun, by a simple noun, or by a full nominal phrase (see section
). The case and agreement features on possessed nouns or nouns acting as possessors are covered here.

text.content: The special affix that occurs on nouns when they are not possessed or pluralized is also discussed.

p.content: As discussed in section
does not have any case system. Therefore, there is no case marking on nouns nor a distinct set of pronouns used for possessors.
Within the normal nominative-accusative case system followed by
, possessors are marked with the genitive case.
Possessors in
are marked with the genitive case, following the normal nominative-accusative part of the split case system. In the parts which display split ergativity, possessors are marked with the

case.caseText: ergative case, the same marking as the subjects of transitive verbs.
absolutive case, the same marking as the subjects of intransitive verbs and the objects of transitive verbs.
genitive case also.

p.content: Within the ergative-absolutive case system followed by
, possessors are marked with the

case.caseText: ergative case, the same marking as the subjects of transitive verbs.
absolutive case, the same marking as the subjects of intransitive verbs and the objects of transitive verbs.
genitive case, a distinct marking for possessors.

p.content: In

case.caseText: The grammatical function of the head noun relative to the verb determines its case, not the presence of a possessor.
The case of the head noun matches the case of the possessor, when a possessor is present.

text.content: If there is an adjective modifier in the nominal phrase, the case of the head noun

case.caseText: only changes when a possessor is present, though the adjective may/must also carry that case.
changes to match the normal case of a possessor even if just an adjectival modifier is present.

text.content: When the overt
genitive
or
ergative
absolutive

case.caseText: suffix
prefix

text.content: is present on the head noun, it indicates that an adjectival modifier and/or a possessor must be present in the phrase. If the adjective is marked with this
genitive
or
ergative
absolutive

case.caseText: suffix,
prefix,

text.content: then another adjective and/or a possessor must also be present.

p.content: In some languages, in a possessed noun phrase the head noun and any modifiers matches the case of the possessor. In other languages, the possessor is marked with its own case, say genitive, while the head noun is marked with case depending on its position relative to the verb: nominative or accusative, ergative or absolutive depending on the case system.
In

case.caseText: the grammatical function of the head noun relative to the verb determines its case, not the presence of a possessor.
the case of the head noun matches the case of the possessor, when a possessor is present.

p.content: Languages like

which change the case of the head noun when a possessor is present normally also change the case of intervening adjectives to match. Some languages of this type also change the case of the head noun when only an adjectival modifier is present, even when there is no possessor.
In
, the case of the head noun

case.caseText: only changes when a possessor is present, though in that situation an intervening adjective may/must also carry that case.
changes to match the normal case of a possessor even if just an adjectival modifier is present.

p.content: Further, some languages of this latter type have an overt affix which marks the genitive case (or the normal case of possessors) on the head noun to indicate that there must be either an adjective or a possessor in that nominal phrase. In this situation, the adjective and/or possessor will also be in genitive case (or the normal case of possessors), though the case marking will not be overt on the highest modifier in the nominal phrase.
In
, the case marking

case.caseText: is not handled via an affix.
is handled in this distinctive way.
is handled in this distinctive way.

text.content: When the overt
genitive
or
ergative
absolutive

case.caseText: suffix
prefix

text.content: is present on the head noun, it indicates that an adjectival modifier and/or a possessor must be present in the phrase. If the adjective is marked with this
genitive
or
ergative
absolutive

case.caseText: suffix,
prefix,

text.content: then another adjective and/or a possessor must also be present.

p.content: Possessor agreement normally comes in two basic forms:

li.content: An affix that occurs on alienably possessed nouns to indicate that they are possessed and therefore must have a possessor in the nominal phrase. Inalienably possessed nouns do not take any marking, but must always have a possessor. These include, but are not limited to, kinship terms and body parts.
An affix that agrees with the possessor (or possibly expresses the possessor by itself).

case.caseText: does not distinguish
makes a distinction

p.content: between alienably and inalienably possessed nouns.

text.content: The affix which marks alienably possessed nouns when they have a possessor is:

p.content: In
, nouns

case.caseText: are not
are

p.content: marked with a pronominal affix or clitic which either agrees with the possessor or expresses the possessor by itself.

text.content: See the dependent personal pronouns used for possessors, given in section

p.content: See section
for examples of possessed nouns.

has an affix that occurs on nouns when they are not possessed or pluralized, or possibly when there are no modifiers. This affix is known as the absolutive marker, but the name is not related to the absolutive case marker used in languages with an ergative-absolutive case system.
The forms of the affix used in
are:

Many languages are like English, in that they have noun modifiers. It may seem like all nouns can also be used as adjectives, but a closer look reveals that true adjectives come before the noun modifier, as in
but not
. Therefore, noun modifiers will be treated as compound nouns which are written as independent words.
In the English examples above,
is clearly the head noun rather than
, because
is restricting the type of
, not the other way around. In all compound nouns and noun modifier constructions in English, the head is the right-most noun in the series.
Noun compounds include those which are combined into a single word as well as those written as two or more independent words. Some typical categories of noun compounds are exemplified here.

caption.content: Compounds describing the Material the Noun is Constructed from

p.content: As shown in the examples,
does not have any compound nouns or noun modifiers that are written as independent words. They are all written as a single word with the head noun.

case.caseText: The left-most noun root is
The right-most noun root is
Either noun root may be

p.content: head in these single-word compounds.
As shown in the examples,
has compound nouns or noun modifiers that are written as independent words.

case.caseText: The left-most noun is
The right-most noun is
Either noun may be

p.content: the head in these multi-word compounds. In the compounds which are written as a single word with the head noun,

case.caseText: the left-most noun root is
the right-most noun root is
either noun root may be

p.content: the head.
